data.title: L.L. Diamond
data.text:
Hi all! I thought to post some Holiday scenes from my books, not always Christmas Day but sometimes the time around it as a fun thing this last week before Christmas. I hope you enjoy this from Unwrapping Mr. Darcy! Youâ€™ll notice I put a photo of Grunt as a chapter break ğŸ™‚

Chapter 5

Light began to permeate the crack in his eyelids, burning a trail along the nerves to his brain. Darcy squeezed them tight and pulled a pillow over his head. Why did it feel like someone was pounding his cranium with a sledgehammer?

A knock vibrated through his skull, and he squeezed the pillow tighter over his ear with a moan.

â€œWilliam? Are you decent?â€

He shifted the pillow so his mouth peeked out the edge. â€œWilliam isnâ€™t here.â€

His sister giggled, and the bed dipped on one side. â€œCome on, sleepyhead. You promised weâ€™d go Christmas tree shopping today.â€

â€œYou were imagining things.â€

â€œNo, I wasnâ€™t. You promised, and Iâ€™m holding you to it.â€ Something rattled on his bedside table. â€œHow much scotch did you drink last night?â€

â€œI went to dinner at Bingley and Janeâ€™s. Had several glasses of wine.â€

â€œAnd then you came home and drank scotch? No wonder youâ€™re such an Oscar the Grouch this morning. You never sleep this late.â€ The bed shifted. â€œIâ€™ll get you some Tylenol and a glass of water. Then I want you to get your behind out of that bed, and shower. You owe me some Christmas shopping today, mister.â€

He exposed part of his face and squinted in an attempt to lessen the piercing pain caused by the light in the room. Why had he forgotten to pull the curtains before he went to bed? Oh, thatâ€™s right. He downed half a bottle of scotch and stumbled to bed without thinking of much. He pushed himself up to a seated position and rubbed his eyes.

Ana returned a few minutes later and handed him two pills, followed by a large glass of water. He swallowed the medicine and drank down the contents of the entire glass before handing it back to her empty.

â€œThank you.â€

â€œDonâ€™t thank me yet. Go get in the shower. Itâ€™s almost time for lunch, and we have some serious decorating to do today.â€

He scanned around the bed, looked down, and frowned. He wasnâ€™t wearing a shirt. Had he gotten naked before he crawled under the covers or had he left on his underwear? Four glasses of wine and that half bottle of scotch rendered his memory a little hazy. He pulled the sheet back just enough to take a peek. â€œUm, Ana?â€

â€œYep,â€ she said as she picked up the empty liquor bottle from beside the bed.

â€œIâ€™m not getting out of this bed with you in the room.â€

Her eyebrows furrowed as she gave him a sidelong look before she flinched. â€œOh! Iâ€™m going!â€ Without any hesitation whatsoever, she was out of the door, and he suddenly had all the privacy he could desire. What he wouldnâ€™t give to sink back into the plush mattress. But he couldnâ€™t. Ana would only come back to wake him again.

With a yawn, a stretch, and a scratch to the back of his thigh, he shuffled into the shower and turned the knobs until a stream of hot water flowed over his head. He leaned his forehead against the grey slate and gave a long, satisfied exhale when the hot water ran in rivulets down his back. The slight sting and the intense heat were heaven and helped ease a lot of the tension from his head and his shoulders.

Forty minutes later, showered and dressed, but not shaved, he walked into the kitchen. His headache had diminished some with the medication and the heat of the shower, but he needed one last thing to bring him back to the land of the living.

â€œCoffee, Mr. Darcy?â€ Mrs. Hill held out his favorite mug, filled to the brim with black, steaming goodness.

â€œYouâ€™re an angel of mercy.â€

The older lady tittered. â€œOh, Mr. Darcy. You sound like Mr. Bingley when you say that.â€ A plate of toast was set before him when he sat at the table. â€œI saw that empty bottle Miss Ana brought down, so I didnâ€™t make you eggs.â€

A burp escaped before he could stop it. â€œExcuse me.â€ He moved the plate closer. â€œThis is perfect, thank you.â€ She patted him on the back and hurried out of the kitchen, passing Ana as she came in.

â€œHey, youâ€™re alive.â€

â€œHa, ha!â€ He leaned back and glanced over what she was wearing. When she hit her teens, Ana went through a major change, shifting from her old pink frills and rainbow unicorns to some of the most interesting combinations of clothes heâ€™d ever seenâ€”and todayâ€™s ensemble was no different. The red tartan plaid skirt she wore had an asymmetrical hem and a leather lace-up waistband. She paired it with thick black leggings, a black turtleneck, and her favorite Dr. Martens, which had red roses embroidered up the sides. She topped off the outfit with a ruby red stud that glittered from the side of her nose.

She grinned and pivoted in a circle. â€œDo you like it?â€

â€œWhat happened to the little girl with pigtails and braces?â€

â€œEw! She gained some style. Thank goodness!â€ She plopped into the chair next to him and took a bite of his toast. â€œSo what made you finish off a bottle of scotch?â€

He snatched his toast back. â€œI donâ€™t want to talk about it.â€

â€œMust be a woman to have you this moody.â€

He stuck his tongue out at her.

â€œThatâ€™s mature.â€ She laughed and rolled her eyes. â€œYou might scare your employees, but you forget that I have access to your baby photos. Iâ€™m not afraid of you.â€

â€œWho would you show them to? Your boyfriend or some of your friends from school? I believe Iâ€™m safe.â€

A wicked gleam lit her eye. â€œNot if I post them as public on social media. One click on Instagram or Twitter and I could ensure the entire world has access.â€

â€œI could say the same to you, little sister.â€

â€œYou could, but youâ€™d have to know how to post something first.â€ Her elbow landed on the table and she leaned her chin in her palm. â€œSo, what drove you to drink last night?â€

â€œHowâ€™s Jacob?â€

â€œMy boyfriend is fine. He has to finish his piece for composition class or he wouldâ€™ve come with me. No changing the subject.â€

â€œPerhaps I donâ€™t want to answer.â€ He took a large bite of toast and started to chew.

â€œI could just ask Charlie.â€

He dropped his hand to the table with a thud. â€œWhy do you have to know?â€

â€œBecause usually you wonâ€™t talk to anyone when youâ€™re upset. You canâ€™t keep everything buried inside that way. Itâ€™s not healthy.â€ She tilted her head a fraction to one side. â€œIs it a woman?â€

He nodded. This was humiliating.

â€œIs she a Caroline?â€

He grimaced. â€œNo.â€

Ana lifted her head just enough to bite her thumbnail while her eyes remained on him. Suddenly, those same hazel eyes widened, and she straightened. â€œOh my God! You like her, but she isnâ€™t interested!â€

His stomach tightened. â€œItâ€™s a little worse than that. She canâ€™t stand me.â€

â€œThen she doesnâ€™t know you. You should make more of an effort. Youâ€™re so reserved and quiet. She needs to know what a great guy you are.â€

â€œItâ€™s not that simple.â€ He tapped his toast on the plate. â€œBingley hired her a few months ago for the legal department. I wanted to wait until Hurst was ready to retire, but Bingley insisted on hiring her then and there. On her first day, he brought her to my office to meet me, but I didnâ€™t want to at that moment. I . . .â€

â€œYou were an imbecile and said something stupid.â€ She sat up straight and crossed her arms over her chest. â€œExactly, how much of an imbecile were you?â€

He rested his forehead in his hand. â€œSheâ€™s Janeâ€™s sister.â€

â€œCharlieâ€™s girlfriend?â€ she asked.

â€œYes, but Elizabeth and Jane are very different. Where Jane is quiet and serene, Elizabeth is fiery and likes to tease.â€

â€œSo, what did you say?â€

He dropped the toast onto the dish and dropped back in his seat. â€œI more or less said I didnâ€™t have time. I also might have implied she got the job because he was dating Jane. She overheard.â€

Ana gasped and a sharp pain in the back of his head whipped his head forward while his brain rattled back and forth against his skull. The Tylenol had kicked in, but it was still a painful shock.

â€œYou hit me!â€

â€œSomeone ought to! Mom and Dad would be ashamed of you. I canâ€™t believe you said that. How long have you known Charlie?â€

â€œAna.â€ He drew out her name.

â€œNo, how long have you known Charlie?â€

â€œSince kindergarten.â€

â€œDad told me all of the time how he first hired Charlie at Darcy Holdings when he was sixteen, and how the two of you worked together there each summer, learning your way around every department. When he graduated from Columbiaâ€™s business program, Dad brought him in as an assistant department head and ensured he finished learning the company inside and out, remember?â€

Darcy nodded and rubbed the back of his head.

â€œDad wasnâ€™t an idiot.â€

He glared at her. â€œI know that.â€

â€œSo why say Charlie hired her for such a stupid reason? You know I once overheard Dad telling Mom why he trained Charlie and hired him into the company like he did.â€

â€œYou never told me about that.â€

â€œI suppose it never occurred to me until now. I think they mustâ€™ve been revising their wills so the topic came up. The point is, Dad knew that if something happened to him, youâ€™d need someone in your corner; someone you could trust to help you run Darcy Holdings. You and I would hold most of the shares of the company and while I was underage, you held mine in trust. Your place as CEO was secure, but he worried about the older executives. He wanted you to have an ally. Fortunately, Charlie never took advantage of Dad and always did an excellent job. Charlie loved Dad and he loves Darcy Holdings. You should know that. You didnâ€™t just insult Elizabeth, you were incredibly insulting to Charlie, too.â€

He slumped in his chair. She was right.

â€œWhen Mom and Dad were killed, Charlie did exactly what he was hired to do. Dadâ€™s last instructions gave him a promotion and a substantial pay increase so he was in precisely the position Dad wanted. Your best friend helped keep you and Darcy Holdings going while you adjusted to the responsibility of CEO and the responsibility of being a single parent to a despondent teenager. He would never do anything to jeopardize the company. If he insisted on hiring Elizabeth at that moment, then he had a damned good reason.â€

â€œHe did. He never explained why though until after he spent over an hour talking her into staying.â€

One side of Anaâ€™s lips curved. â€œShe tried to quit on her first day? I like her. She wonâ€™t take your crap.â€

â€œThanks a lot.â€

She grinned. â€œDonâ€™t mention it.â€ After a moment, she wagged a finger at him. â€œI think I can guess what happened after that. You passed her in the hallways, finally got a good look at her, and found yourself attracted to her. Sheâ€™s definitely no slouch at her job or you wouldnâ€™t care how hot she is, you wouldâ€™ve dismissed her at the first sign of laziness or incompetence. Now, she probably wonâ€™t interact with you above the barest civilities outside of work, and you donâ€™t know how to fix things.â€

He swallowed hard. â€œAm I that predictable?â€

His little sister laughed softly. â€œProbably only to me and Charlie. So, what happened last night?â€

â€œCharlie and Jane invited me to dinner. Elizabeth was there. I wanted a moment alone with her to apologize, but anytime she realized she would be left without a buffer, she ran for it. Because of the cold weather, I gave her a ride home, and I finally managed to get in that apology.â€

â€œHowâ€™d she take it?â€

â€œAlright, I suppose. She thanked me.â€

Ana put her hand over his. â€œYouâ€™re probably going to have to prove yourself to make her believe it. I hope you know that.â€

He nodded. â€œI walked her to her door despite her protests that it wasnâ€™t necessary. I even helped her clean up the broken glass from her cat until she insisted she could do it herself. I didnâ€™t want to force my presence on her.â€

â€œNo, I think thatâ€™s the last thing you should do. Just keep trying to speak to her. Make her see who you are.â€

â€œWow.â€ He tugged at the end of the long auburn braid she had resting over her shoulder. â€œWhen did you grow up?â€

â€œWho says Iâ€™ll ever grow up? Now, eat the last of your breakfast. I want a Christmas tree.â€

He picked up what was left of his toast, put his plate in the dishwasher, and waved her to follow. â€œLetâ€™s go. I can eat this while we walk. The tree lot isnâ€™t that far.â€

She gave a girlish squeal and tore from the kitchen. When he met her in the huge foyer, she was decked out in her heavy coat with a tartan cap and scarf.

The moment they were walking in the direction of the tree lot, he nudged her with his elbow. â€œSo, howâ€™s school going?â€

â€œThe same as always. You know I live for it. My cello professor has me learning a Bach piece that I absolutely love.â€

He took a half-step to the side and looked at her. â€œYouâ€™ve never been a huge fan of Bach.â€

â€œI know!â€ Her eyes sparkled, and her voice sounded a little breathless. He was familiar with that look and the slight tremor in her voice. â€œI adore this one, though. Itâ€™s difficult technically, but so much fun to play, and I like the melody as well. I canâ€™t wait for you to hear it.â€ She wouldnâ€™t just master this piece, sheâ€™d perfect it, just as sheâ€™d done to the all of the pieces she became infatuated with.

â€œWhenever youâ€™re ready for an audience, I look forward to hearing it.â€

She skipped a few paces ahead and turned to walk backward. â€œWeâ€™re getting a big tree, arenâ€™t we? I know you said it wasnâ€™t necessary, but it wouldnâ€™t be the same. Besides, how would we choose which ornaments to leave in the boxes and which to put on?â€

â€œYouâ€™re going to Maine with Jacob, so it will be just me and Mr. and Mrs. Hill. Charlie invited me to spend Christmas Day with them, so I donâ€™t need a huge tree. If you didnâ€™t want to decorate one so badly, Iâ€™d probably not even bother this year.â€ They rounded the corner and crossed the street.

â€œThen Iâ€™m glad I made you come out to buy one. Everyone should have a Christmas tree.â€

â€œWhat if someone is Jewish?â€

Ana gave a slight snort. â€œYou know what I mean.â€

He smiled and took her hand. â€œCome on, letâ€™s pick out a tree.â€

When they reached the small corner of the park cordoned off as a tree lot, they walked through the rows of fir and spruce trees, all different shapes and sizes. Of course, Ana chose the biggest Noble Fir they had with a tremendous toothy grin. He didnâ€™t need such an extravagant Christmas tree, but he couldnâ€™t say no when it made her so happy. At Christmas, she behaved with some of the mannerisms she had when she was a little girl. The glimpse of that child made every penny he spent worth it.

She bounced up to him. â€œTree taken care of. You just need to go pay.â€

â€œAnd set it up for delivery.â€

â€œWe could carry it home.â€

He glanced over her shoulder at what had to be a fourteen-foot tree. â€œNot on your life. Youâ€™d be complaining by the end of the first block.â€ Before she could make a sarcastic comment, he pinched her side and walked by to go talk to the lot manager.

Five minutes later, he was the proud owner of a Christmas tree. Fortunately for them, most people carried their trees home, so the man was willing, for a hefty price, of course, to load theirs up and deliver it. He slid his credit card back into his wallet and glanced around for Ana, who was next to the wreaths.

After a quick text to Mr. and Mrs. Hill to warn them of the treeâ€™s impending invasion. He returned to Ana and tugged her braid. â€œWhat are you doing, Squirt?â€

She pointed ahead of them. â€œLook, itâ€™s Charlie and Jane. Iâ€™ve never met her, but he posts a lot of pictures of her on Instagram. Sheâ€™s very pretty.â€

He glanced over, his gaze not landing on Bingley or Jane, but on the brunette a few trees down. Her eyes glowed, and a small smile tugged at her lips as she touched a branch, stroking the needles.

â€œIs that Elizabeth?â€

He started. Anaâ€™s cheek was right next to his shoulder. â€œYes, thatâ€™s her.â€

â€œSheâ€™s pretty. Not in the usual way, though. I think itâ€™s her eyes. Theyâ€™re very expressive.â€

â€œDarcy!â€ He turned as Bingley approached and kissed Ana on the cheek. â€œHow are you, Squirt?â€

She crossed her arms over her chest and huffed. â€œNot you, too.â€

Bingley chuckled as Jane walked up and hugged Darcy. â€œThank you for seeing my sister home last night. I know she was probably a big grump over it, but I canâ€™t thank you enough.â€

â€œReally, it was no bother.â€ He put a hand to Anaâ€™s back. â€œAna, Iâ€™d like you to meet Jane Bennet.â€

Jane beamed as she shook Anaâ€™s hand with both of hers. â€œIâ€™ve heard so much about you from Charlie and your brother.â€

â€œIâ€™ve heard a lot about you as well.â€

â€œDid the two of you pick out a tree?â€ asked Bingley.

â€œAna selected one. Iâ€™m just the poor sod with the credit card.â€

â€œLizzy wanted to pick out a tree today, so we all came out together.â€ Jane glanced over both shoulders. â€œI wonder where she went?â€

â€œWeâ€™ll let you get back to her.â€ Darcy put a hand to Anaâ€™s elbow, starting to steer her forward. â€œI promised Ana some hot chocolate from Gouldingâ€™s, and we still have to make a stop to buy her a new ornament.â€

Janeâ€™s eyebrows raised slightly.

â€œWhen she was born, my mother started the tradition of buying her a special ornament every year, so when she has her own family, she has a collection for her own tree.â€

â€œWhat a wonderful idea! Well, we wonâ€™t keep you. It was nice to meet you, Ana.â€

His sister nodded. â€œIt was nice to meet you, too. See you later, Charlie.â€

After Ana and Jane both gave a quick wave, he led Ana across the street to Gouldingâ€™s coffee shop and straight to the counter.

â€œYou donâ€™t want me to meet Elizabeth?â€ She looked up to him with a sly smile on her lips.

â€œYou know better than that. You agreed I shouldnâ€™t push, and after last night, she was probably hiding from me.â€

â€œWilliam,â€ she said, drawing out his name.

â€œNo, Iâ€™ll see her tomorrow at the Monday morning planning session. Iâ€™m not giving up. Iâ€™m just giving her a break.â€

â€œDonâ€™t give her too much of a break. She might find someone else.â€

Elizabeth wandered through the trees touching the lush needles and breathing in the smell. She loved that scent! It meant Christmas was here. She pulled a tag from the tree she wanted and glanced around. Where had Jane and Charlie gone? When she backtracked through the trees, she stopped when she found them standing on the other side of the lot talking to Mr. Darcy, who had a woman on his arm.

Something about seeing the girl touch his arm made her want to slap him. What was up with that? Who was the woman and why would she want to hit him for being with her? Elizabeth squinted. The lady was graceful and attractive, but seemed . . . young, very young compared to him. No one ever mentioned a girlfriend, but who else could she be?

Elizabeth started over to say hello, but he and the girl walked off while Jane and Charlie started back towards her. â€œSorry, were you looking for us? The trees are nice this year, donâ€™t you think?â€ Her sister ran her fingers along the needles of a nearby branch. â€œDid you see William? He was just here buying a tree, too.â€

â€œI saw him when I came looking for you.â€ They started to walk further into the trees while Charlie followed behind. â€œWho was the girl?â€ Why did she ask that? Why did it peeve her that he was there with a woman? She didnâ€™t even like him. â€œI donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve ever heard of him dating anyone.â€ Oh, good grief! Why hadnâ€™t she stopped before that came out?

Janeâ€™s eyes narrowed a bit. â€œThat girl wasnâ€™t his date, but even if she was, what difference would it make?â€

â€œOkay, his friend.â€ Elizabeth attempted to walk around Jane, but her sister stepped in front of her.

â€œAna is Williamâ€™s little sister. Sheâ€™s quite a bit younger than he is and attends college here in the city. He brought her out to buy a Christmas tree.â€

â€œHe did?â€

â€œYes, Charlie has told me theyâ€™re very close. Theyâ€™ve had to be since William raised Ana after their parents were killed by a drunk driver.â€

â€œOh, I vaguely remember the headlines after the accident, but I didnâ€™t remember that he had a younger sister.â€

â€œI think she was about sixteen, which wouldâ€™ve made him about thirty. It couldnâ€™t have been easy.â€ Jane peered back over her shoulder toward Gouldingâ€™s. â€œCould you imagine having to suddenly take over raising Lydia for Mom and Dad?â€

Elizabeth shuddered. â€œMom and Dad better not go anywhere until Lydia can take care of herself. She couldnâ€™t live with me. Iâ€™d throw her out the window before the first week was out.â€

Jane giggled and shook her head. â€œLizzy!â€

â€œWell, itâ€™s true! Not everyone is as patient as you are. Now, you and Charlie need to pick out a tree.â€ Elizabeth held up her ticket. â€œI found one right over there. Iâ€™m going to go pay for mine, so we can carry them back.â€ She made her way through the trees until she found the man to pay. While she waited for him to run her card, she watched the people around herâ€”the childrenâ€™s happy faces as they ran through the maze of trees, the people walking by with shopping bags, and the customers leaving Gouldingâ€™s with steaming cups cradled in both of their hands.

She froze. That wasnâ€™t some random person, it was Mr. Darcy. He spoke with the woman sheâ€™d seen him with earlier, his sister, pointing down one way then the other. She couldnâ€™t stop herself from staring. He was wearing jeans. Sheâ€™d never seen him wear anything but suits, but William Darcy actually owned jeansâ€”and was that stubble on his cheeks? He hadnâ€™t shaved?

Despite the cold day this warm sensation began to spread from her stomach through her body. She shifted to get a look at his sister, but instead, met the girlâ€™s eyes and immediately turned away, her cheeks hot. What was that?

Happy Monday! Iâ€™m spending this week revisiting holiday scenes from some of my books. Today is an excerpt from my newest, An Endeavour to be Worthy!

â€œMerry Christmas, Mr. Darcy,â€ said Mr. Gideon when he opened the front door.

â€œMerry Christmas, Mr. Gideon.â€ He and Georgiana happened to greet the butler in unison, making the man beam as they entered.

The man helped Darcy with his coat while several maids appeared to be of aid to the ladies. â€œI hope church was enjoyable.â€ For the first time, Mr. Gideonâ€™s slight accent was noticeable.

â€œThe service was lovely,â€ said Miss Elizabeth. â€œMy grandparents, Lord Hatton, and Miss Montford will be directly behind us. We shall await them in the green drawing room.â€

â€œVery good, miss. We shall be ready for their arrival.â€

Miss Jane wrung her hands. â€œDo you think they are well?â€

â€œI am certain they will be here soon,â€ said Darcy. Due to the delay, they may have been caught in traffic.â€ Bingley had never been a violent man, yet he had never expected Bingley to fall into such debt either.

A commotion in the front hall announced the rest of their partyâ€™s arrival. When Darcy peered at Miss Elizabeth, he could not miss the heavy exhale and the manner in which her body relaxed.

Lady Richmond was the first to enter the drawing room, making her way to Miss Jane and sitting beside her. The two spoke in hushed tones as the earl and Hatton entered. Georgiana joined Miss Jane and the countess and offered the latter her hand. Perhaps the similarity of their experiences would deepen their friendship. He had no objections. Georgiana would only benefit from such an association.

He stepped over to Lord Richmond and Hatton with Miss Elizabeth close behind. â€œI am not sure what Bingley hoped to accomplish.â€

â€œHe surely hoped to force a meeting with Janey,â€ said Lord Richmond. â€œNicholas restrained him while we boarded our carriage. That Miss Bingley woman approached and attempted to ingratiate herself to Amelia, but Amelia and my wife cut her. Lady Jersey, as well as Lady Dalrymple and Miss Carteret were nearby and witnessed the exchange. I am certain those who are in London for Christmastide will know before the first of January.â€

â€œEnough!â€ When he turned, Lady Richmond was standing with her hands raised in front of her. â€œâ€™Tis Christmas, and we shall not dwell any longer on the Bingleys but enjoy our day. Now, we have gifts for each of you. Fitzwilliam, I shall not accept a refusal.â€

He and Miss Elizabeth sat upon the settee as the countess distributed her packages. While she handed Miss Elizabeth a box, the earl handed him a bottle. â€œMy wife charged me with finding you a gift. I hope you approve.â€ The older gentleman wore a slight smile.

When he took the bottle, he turned it in his hands to view the label. â€œAn excellent brandy. I thank you.â€

â€œBrandy, my lord,â€ said the countess with her lips pursed.

â€œHe purchases the latest books as soon as Hatchardâ€™s puts them on the shelves, and they had nothing newer than a month ago, which I am certain he already possesses. What would you have me buy?â€

â€œLady Richmond, I must admit your husband is correct. I do not require much, and this will be savoured since Richard drank my last bottle of this vintage six months ago, and I have been unable to procure more.â€

â€œFor heavenâ€™s sakes, do not let the colonel near it then,â€ said the earl. â€œI had no idea he was so intemperate.â€

â€œHe does enjoy a good brandy, but I was at Pemberley for the summer while he lived at Darcy House, not long after he was assigned to Horse Guards.â€ Richard could drink quite a bit and keep his wits about him, but he was not one to drink an entire bottle of brandy in one sitting.

Miss Elizabeth opened the lid of her box and gasped. â€œGrandmamma, you have given me so much jewellery since my arrival. I do not require so much.â€ Nestled in velvet was a necklace with a pendant that resembled a snowflake. Diamonds set in gold with the larger stones in the centre and becoming smaller as they neared the tips.

â€œNonsense. This is the last of your motherâ€™s jewels that was set aside for you, as is Janeâ€™s gift.â€

Miss Jane flipped open the lid on hers and inhaled swiftly. â€œGrandmamma, this is lovely.â€ She turned it to show Miss Elizabeth the modest sapphire necklace and matching ear drops.

His sister held a stack of music sheets and a cashmere shawl sat upon her lap. â€œFitzwilliam, what of our gifts?â€

After he excused himself, he ducked out into the hall where Mr. Gideon happened to be passing. â€œPardon me, but a servant from Darcy House was supposed to deliver some gifts while we were at church.â€

â€œAh, yes,â€ said Mr. Gideon. â€œForgive me. I forgot to mention it upon your arrival.â€ He stepped inside a doorway on one side and brought out a small trunk. â€œWhere would you like it?â€

â€œI can take it. Thank you,â€ he said. When he returned to the drawing room, he withdrew two packages and handed them to Georgiana, who in turn, gave them to Miss Amelia and Miss Jane. Meanwhile, he passed gifts to Lord and Lady Richmond and Hatton. Lastly, he returned to Miss Elizabethâ€™s side and passed her the last.

â€œâ€™Tis from Georgiana and I both.â€

She gave him a side-long look, but her fingers trembled ever-so-slightly while she peeled away the silk paper. â€œHow beautiful. Thank you.â€

â€œWhat is it Lizzybeth?â€ asked her grandmother.

With a careful touch, she lifted it from the wrapping. â€œA hair comb.â€

â€œWhich will be lovely in your dark hair.â€ Her grandmother admired the piece, then stepped over to sit close to her husband while she removed the paper from hers. â€œWhat gorgeous silk! Thank you, Fitzwilliam. I must admit I adore a trip to Madame Morisotâ€™s, and you have given me just the excuse.â€

â€œYes, thank you Darcy,â€ said the earl dryly.

Miss Amelia and Miss Jane thanked both him and Georgiana for the fabric in their packages. Hatton clapped him on the shoulder after expressing his appreciation of the journal he had received, and Lord Richmond gave a hearty laugh when he saw the bottle of brandy Darcy had gifted him. â€œGreat minds think alike, do they not, Darcy?â€

â€œI had just managed to find a shipment a few days ago.â€ His attention returned to Miss Elizabeth, who fingered through the material that was beneath the hair comb. â€œYou have given me fabric as well?â€

Her grandmother chuckled. â€œHe has selected well. You have always looked well in rose, and you will need a great many gowns for the Season.â€

â€œLady Richmond, breakfast is served.â€
